TopicTitle: Matching orbit to Minmus, just outside SOI?

Articles.Content:
I want to put a satellite in an orbit that matches Minmus, and is just outside it's SOI. Two, in fact, on in front and one behind.

I'm trying to set up a Kerbin system comms network (using RemoteTech). After working throgh various options on paper, the most efficient, it seemed to me, would be to place two satellites each for Mun and Minmus, matching orbits, outside of their SOI, one just in front, one just behind, with dishes pointed at the moons and back at Kerbin (where I already have a 4-satellite network setup.)

I've managed to do this for the Mun. But with a bit of difficulty. I started by entering an eliptical orbit where the Ap matched the Mun and where the closest to target position was at the Ap, and that distance was just beyond the Mun's SOI. With the plan to simply circularise the orbit at the Ap.

However, despite the patched conics not showing as such, this managed to trap me in the Mun's SOI during the approach to the Ap (clearly the closest positions marker was wrong...). Thankfully I'd budgeted about 2km/s more Dv than I needed and managed to salvage the mission and have the satellites for the Mun setup now.

The same thing has happened with my Minmus approach, but I do not have enough Dv to correct the course. So have simply sent it to crash on Kerbin and am planning to try it again.

Is there a better wayto match orbits with Minmus (but not be captured by it) than the method I gave above? Or do I simply need to use that method but give more distance at the Ap to avoid being captured by the SOI in advance of the Ap?

A) first off, beware SOI inflation. Many of my vessels had unexpected encounters -- to the best of my knowledge, this happens during timewarp. "Just outside some body's SOI" may be quite unstable in practice.

![B)](//kerbal-forum-uploads.s3.us-west-2.amazonaws.com/emoticons/default_cool.png) how to: either approach the point from behind (coming from a higher orbit) or accept that you will pass through the moon's SOI (and try to leave it in just the right place).

KSP's orbit calculations aren't precise enough to get something like this working. You can't even really expect to get 3 satellites orbiting in tandem, without them wandering a bit over time. Only with that situation, it's usually not an instant catastrophe when they wander.

No matter what you do, eventually this will fail and more likely than not, you won't notice it until you need that satellite, find out it's gone, and are surprised to learn it's now orbiting the Sun.

I love RemoteTech and play it all the time. What I generally do for Mun or Minmus is to just put a couple of satellites in polar orbits, at right angles to each other, at as high a circular orbit as they can be while sticking inside the SoI. I give them each a DTS-M1 pointed at Kerbin, and a 5000km omni antenna.

In practice, this does the trick. They give pretty good coverage over the body's surface, they almost always can see each other, and at least one of them (usually both) see Kerbin. It works out pretty well.
